Snark says what?
 
Holy sh--  I left off at what post?  Gotta try to be brief then, somehow, never managed before.  Brief with a side of spoilers…
 
Post 2034.  Twentysome pages ago, using the long form.
Okay, so Odin and the boys of the Hunt get some motorcycles and make a run for it, which surely couldn’t work except that, for one of them, it does.  Artemis, privately in cahoots, privately gives Glen the name of that one.  And he’s in the wind in L.A.  And there’s an argument in the party about whether smashing Dando’s skull was something We Angels are supposed to do.
No such argument about whether We Angels should loot Kingman’s place though, and there they acquire a Discord Doll belonging to William Squire, highly delusional center of all good gossip in L.A. Glen grabs a few things, including a Castling artifact, and hauls them all out of there before the demons get too close and they all head to Kane’s place in Pomona.
Ryuki prepares to meet his new direct superior, a Judge who calls himself Judge Stone.  Mitch catches up with the cherub Dennis, and Glen moves all the goodies to his home, or was it his shop?  Glen’s demon batteries/hostages don’t go anywhere, but the same cannot be said for his ethereal black hound.  And Sunae and Kane, passengers in Alex’s car, pick up a ghost hitchhiker with a message from the ethereals.  Dennis will watch out for the wandering Hunter and pay off his debt to Ruby. 
 
Kane tells Corat that he’s heard rumors of attacks against major tethers.  Sunae thinks that’s serious, but Corat figures there’s no way Hell would make open attacks.  Corat is wrong.
Ryuki gathers everyone at the office for giggles at Ruby’s expense and giggles at Judge Stone’s expense. He throws in an old kimono with some interesting history—actually he throws the location of same to Ruby, in a stage production in Santa Cruz.  Let’s see if she takes that bait.  She also wants taxes on Kingman’s stuff and is threatening to make L.A. very inhospitable if she doesn’t get them.
(2401)
Corat runs out, leaving you his phone.  There’s a text message: The text reads: "911 direct atk. This is war". It's from Dig(nity), the Seneschal of the Dream tether at the movie theater you were at earlier.
 
War just went hot. It’s not the Dream theater under attack, it’s the War tether at Pohang where a bunch of teenaged kids bought their nation’s survival with their lives.  Dig tells everyone to stay in San Fran, that Pohang is a slaughter, but Kane’s a Malakite and jumps through the rapidly shrinking portal that is the other end of the tether.  He’s hopelessly outnumbered but manages to save his fellow Malakim from a fate worse than death:  captivity.  A local cherub/sniper sends Kane back to Heaven at some expense, but at least there are no hostages. At the theater, Judge Stone gives Mitch his true name Briathos and tries to corral the folks there. Presumptuous like a Judge.   Ruby calls to swear it’s not her, that it has to be Baal’s boys retaliating for all the party’s been doing in L.A.  She’s mostly right, but missing one piece of the puzzle—what else is eating Baal?  She does tell you that the next attack will be on Kumamoto Castle.
 
(2494)

Characters in Mile Higher Club/The Pacific War, in approximate order clockwise from upper left The Wild Hunt--ethereals from a mixed British and Norse mythos.  A small contingent helped track Frank/Ah Pukuh, but the bulk of them remained in the Dreams where they were clearly plotting to help their fellows escape their angelic handlers. Hereward the Wake--ethereal, in life an 11th century British hero Dando of the Dogs--ethereal, in life a fallen priest.  His fight helped von Galen escape. Bernhard von Galen--nobleman/bishop of Munster, 17th century Germany.  Like Hereward he also travels with the Hunt, but alone among them escaped into Los Angeles.  Of the party, only Glen knows his name. Artemis--Greek goddess of the moon and the hunt, not usually associated with the Wild Hunt but sent to accompany them.  She told Glen about von Galen.    (not pictured--the Olympians, one of a few pantheons that survives the Ban intact) the ghost hitchhiker--common urban legend become ethereal.  Delivered the ethereals' message to the party, identified the party by Dando's blood on their hands, er, handkerchief Baron Samedi, Loa   Puckish ethereal trickster well embroiled in celestial affairs.  Generally considered a benign pain in the butt, but occasionally chafes outwardly at angelic standards Papa Legba, the father and leader of the Loa.  Wise enough to keep his mouth shut Frank/Ah Pukuh, a hybrid of a Mayan slaughter god and an imprisoned Balseraph of the War.  Based loosely on Uncle Frank from Hellraiser.  Kingman set him loose for maximum impact.  While tracking him the party crossed paths with Ruby, who was possibly trying to contain the situation, and Ajosshi who was attracted by the noise.  He was also actively assisted by Tishbite and his compatriots.     (not pictured, his paramour Julia, the ghost of the lover he killed) Jerry Kingman, sorcerer dying of cancer and trying to get out of his deal.  Kane sent him onward.  His lair contained references to New Age beliefs, kitschy Egyptology, and a smattering of Santeria. his apprentice DeShawn, young man last seen in a tailcoat and top hat Ryuki's late uncle Shiro, died violently after brokering a family truce and summoned to use as leverage against Ryuki Miyako the younger, Mia Watari.  Was an occasional customer of Jerry Kingman's. (not pictured, Ryuki's father Ryukawa, stepmother Miyako, sister Mia, brother Ken, bodyguard Scott Green, and unnamed family in Nagasaki) Ryuki Watari, primary NPC.  Banking heir, born Creation soldier, and sorcerer.  Currently IST Dominic. "angels", Kingman believed that Ryuki's fascination with angels had provided him with angelic contacts he could use to help him. Briathos, his immediate supervisor and trainer.  An Elohite that appears to have a sense of humor, or cluelessness, hard to tell Dominic, the archangel Nisroc, angel of Spies, technically answers to Michael but acts as a 'red phone' between he and Dominic.  Directly aided the party in the house attack with/against Ruby and against Ajosshi. Michael, archangel of War Corat, primary NPC, Ofanite.  Formerly of Wind as a pilgrimage guide, now of War beginning as a spy recruiter.  A transition like this can lead to instability in an angel. 1973 Triad, Tokyo.  Convicted Corat in a case involving tampering by Michael of a seraph of the Sword. unnamed seraph of the Sword.  Held the deciding vote in the case and was undecided until approached by Michael Laurence, his superior Hamael, Word of Dignity, his servitor.  Appears to have some relationship with Soldekai (not pictured), though that may simply be similar temperaments. Methariel, PC seraph of the Sword (MHC), vetted Ryuki for Laurence.  As much as Ryuki enjoyed toying with him, his clarity is definitely missed by the young soldier as he navigates celestial politics Miyamoto Musashi--Saint of the Sword and military hero of old Japan.  Fought against the Christians at Amakusa Dignity (not the be confused with Hamael, whose Word is Dignity and on whom she has a crush), Seneschal of the theater tether of Dreams.  Apparently well-acquainted with Corat. Blandine, archangel of Dreams David, archangel of Stone Janus, archangel of the Wind Mahmud, malakite of Faith, friend of Hamael "Hunter", pseudonym of a Tsayadim friend of Mahmud's and possibly Hamael's Khalid, archangel of Faith, but Hunter's superior? Marc, archangel of Trade Mitchem, PC, his servitor in the hostile territory of Los Angeles, and has been so for some time. Zahirah, PC Bright Lilim, formerly of Faith, now up above being remade by Novalis Novalis, archangel of Flowers.  Active in Hawaii, among other places Gabriel, archangel of Fire.  Very unstable, and stays apart from the other archangels.  Holds a tether on Kilauea in tandem with Pele.  Sponsored Sunae's family directly while keeping them apart from all others. Dennis the Firebug, former Djinn in L.A., recently redeemed by Marc with Mitch's guidance, servitor of Gabriel.  Based loosely on Denis Leary Ashbel, PC servitor of Fire Grandpa, Saint of Fire, technically Sunae's great-great-times x grandfather.  A very harsh master which tends to rile those around him.  Ashbel, Ryuki, and Marty among others have already promised him grievous bodily harm. Sunae, PC, Soldier of Fire James "Kahuna" Bouchier, reformed sorcerer.  Damned and subsequently brought to redemption by Zahirah, though his redemption is contingent on staying away from sorcery.  Ryuki's teacher since the age of eleven.  Priest of Pele, who offered him purpose and shelter from demons.  Godfather to Grace. (not pictured) Lei'alani, mother of Grace,  ex-fling and now co-parent with Ryuki.  Regards Kahuna as a wise friend. Zahirah, PC.  Bright Lilim, formerly a mere Lilim, switched from Faith to Flowers.  It was she who first damned Kahuna, and she who brought him back.  She has met Grace in person though at this point Grace's dad does not yet know it. Kane, servitor of Eli currently in service to David. Pele, goddess and former princess of Hawaii.  She has a tether at Kilauea and an active cult on the islands, fed in part by superstitious tourists Ruby, Lilim, and functionally the demon queen of Los Angeles since no earlier than 2000.  She 'rules' the renegade town through a network of favors owed, though she's had to compete with Ryuki for business.  The rivalry between the two of them seems to work well for running the town, at least so far. Ajosshi, Knight of the Game, sent to L.A. to quiet things down and perhaps knock the Lilim queen down to size.  While his mission failed, it may have let Hell see that angels were working with her, or at least not actively against her, to achieve mutual ends. Asmodeus, the Game.  The slippery status of Los Angeles might be a problem for him, or it might be a cudgel to beat other demons--and angels--with. Baal, demon price of The War.  He can't be happy that angels are moving openly in Los Angeles, when less than 20 years ago they were humiliated and slaughtered.  The attack on Pohang could be a counterattack in his mind.  He is certainly encouraging Michael to think in that direction, wanting to heat up The War and get it done with. William Squire, renegade Balseraph.  In his delusions he believed he was the puppetmaster of the entire War, but in practice he was an excellent spy, able to track Baal and Michael's secret meetings through a combination of skill and luck.  Numerous discords from being reminded that he was not in fact the puppetmaster were put into a discord doll.  That doll was being held for safekeeping by Jerry Kingman who may or may not have understood its significance. Lilith, demon princess of Freedom.  Superior to Ruby (or not?) and former superior to Zahirah. Eli, archangel of Creation.  Blessed Kumiko while she was in the womb, and so is technically Ryuki's superior.  Is also Kane's superior.  Kumiko was one of many so blessed, and while at the time he was acting more or less randomly, before his walkabout he would have been able to create the conditions where this would happen on purpose. Pepito, impudite of Dark Humor. A "sick puppy" i.e. a demon too stupid to serve Kobal effectively so he was placed in the role of a child in order to corrupt his caretakers.  This position allowed him to spin Corat towards a fall, leading to at least one discord.  Went to school with Danae the telepath (listed under "other spies"). Tishbite, Tyura, and Golmorath, canon demons from L. Rel.  Tishbite imprisoned the other two inside televisions as part of a failed project meant to impress his superior Vapula.  Tishbite connected with Frank, using his technical skills to help Frank communicate and possibly enlist his aid to stay out of the private room in Hell Vapula has no doubt prepared for him.  Tyura and Golmorath help Tishbite stay out not because they like him in any way but because their mere existence will make them a target for Hell's wrath. Vapula, demon prince of Technology Hosogawa Tadotoshi, late daimyo of Kumamoto Castle and friend and sponsor to Musashi in life.  Now revered as a kami. The kami, gods of Japan including deceased relatives and other people who were noteworthy in life.  In order to survive they made a deal with Nybbas in the post-war era to spread their image worldwide.  Despite the demon's fine print and the disdain of fellow ethereals, the kami survived and fulfilled the contract, ending it recently to Nybbas' frustration. Nybbas, demon prince of The Media.  Took a loss in Japan but sees opportunity in Los Angeles. Beleth, demon princess of Nightmares. Baku-ya and two accomplices, nightmare demons behind the attempted attack against Kumamoto Castle. the Dylan twins, Bill and Ed, detained in the Loa compound where it was insinuated that they were spying there. Marty, Kevin, and other spies, recruited by Corat for Nisroc, their existence is supposed to be a secret.

Since it is wildly impractical to do Snark at work... characters Snark--narration voice of the GM. Usually gives attitude with her summaries, occasionally gives spoilers or other underlying information. Corat--Now a Wheel of War, he's still adjusting to the transition. A longtime guide, he chafes when asked to lead, preferring to offer advice over giving orders--yet a Malakite needs orders. Adding to his discomfort is the appeal of his conviction over the Yasukuni pilgrimage. Sure it would be nice to clean Dominic's proverbial house, but why now? Why now that his memories of the events are all but gone? Why exonerate a Warrior when an odd mix of characters is setting fire to a cold war? Ryuki Watari--Now a Soldier of Judgement, though a very newly minted one. This decision has received a slightly warmer reception than he expected, and he's keeping mum about some of his reasons for making it. Some of them, though, were laid bare by Dominique. He thinks that with Nisroc's intervention and his own wiles he can keep the secrets dear to him from the old inquisitor-seraph, but Corat at least thinks he's being incredibly naive, and this has put a tiny wedge in their friendship. Ryuki, in his infinite humility, intends to save the world from the celestial war that has made his life so 'interesting'. The Infernals Ruby—unaffiliated Lilim, de facto demon queen of Los Angeles. She has something of a pact with the angels of the party. She definitely has a rivalry with Ryuki, and he functions as an alternative for demons who want to make a deal but don't want to pay her prices. She knows basically everything there is to know about the city, and will sell it to you at a price... William Squire—Balseraph. Somehow the late Gerald Kingman ended up with his Discord doll, showing that Squire is very much on the edge. Squire will tell you that he is the puppetmaster of demonkind, certainly an all-knowing kind of guy, but either he's becoming a good guy or that's just not true. Ajosshi—the latest in a long line of Gamesters to walk into L.A. expecting to make it their town, only to get shown the door without their vessels. Big, powerful and smart, but still not enough. His favorite soldier, unnamed. Also killed in that battle. Tishbite and his three companions. Balseraph Baron of Technology, with Golmorath, Impudite Knight of Nightmares; Tyura, Impudite Baron of Fire; and Sandernog, Impudite Baron of the Media. They're at cross-purposes, but they agree on one thing: don't get caught. (L. Reliquarum, canon characters) Princes involved so far: Asmodeus, who's bothered by the appearance that they've lost L.A. Sending in guys like Ajosshi is a win-win for him though—either they get humiliated or they win the town. Asmodeus sends his most egotistical guys into this assignment. Baal, who's bothered by the possibility that they've lost L.A. and is eager for a counterattack. Kobal should be concerned about the amount of firepower brought to bear on a mere sick puppy, but he's still laughing at how an idiot Impudite could cost Heaven so many resources. The Celestials Corat, who answers to Ihi'Velga, who answers to Nisroc, who answers to Michael and occasionally to Dominic. Nisroc, word of Spies—still the only real line of communication between Michael and Dominic, outside of some very formal words at the Seraphim Council. Judge Stone/Briathos, Elohite.—Ryuki's Dominican recruiter and at this point his direct superior. Hamael, word of Dignity, well-regarded Malakite of the Sword. Methariel's direct superior. Mahmud, Malakite of Faith, his Tsayadim friend. He probably has more than one. Derek, Kyriotate seneschal of the red-eye tether of Wind, 767 from Honolulu to Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle and Denver and back. Dignity, Cherub seneschal of the Hilltop Theater tether of Dreams in San Francisco. Elias, seneschal of the soul food restaurant tether of Creation in Los Angeles. ? , seneschal of the ice cream truck tether of Trade in Los Angeles. Jasmine, estranged friend of Corat's, Mercurian of Flowers and a stripper by trade. L.A. resident. Archangesl interested so far:  Michael, Dominic, Novalis, Eli. The Ethereals The Loa, notably the Baron Samedi and their leader Papa Legba. They are allied with Heaven which has caused friction with the other ethereals, though since their concept is of gods to the downtrodden they're not completely shunned. If anything they're rather popular these days, throwing wonderful parties. The Lord of Misrule, capable of leading a mob at a party. The Aesir and the Olympians receive Essence from their place in the Western canon and in pop culture. Certainly they have to fight neophyte pretenders for that Essence, but it's coming in enough to ensure their survival. The Wild Hunt contains members of the Aesir, spirits of dead heroes and legends of Anglo-Saxon folklore, proving that ethereals can band together. This surprises most ethereals, who tend to be highly tribal. Among them Christoph Bernhard von Galen. In life a 17th century prince and bishop who knew his way around a battlefield and enjoyed hunting. Hereward the Wake, among other epithets. An 11th century English hero known for his chivalry and the loyalty he inspired in others. The Japanese pantheon has just thrown off their Media masters, but their allegiances are not yet known. Ah Pukuh, the ethereal half of “Frank”. Mayan god of death and slaughter, seduced the ghost who goes by Julia. He was defeated and exiled, and probably near-dead. Black Shuck, one-eyed hound of the English highways, known for protecting lone women and meting out vigilante justice. And being a dog. Certain denizens of the spirit jars Ghosts and others Julia—the adoring and scheming lover of “Frank”. Dream soldiers the Dylan brothers. Ryuki's late uncle Shiro Watari. The girl-guide he spoke of in the afterlife, a ghostlike recording put there by angels of Destiny to tell the newly-dead where they are and where they should go. Ryuki's mother and daughter, both affected by Eli's gift. His FWB Bobbi. Family friends and business partners the Ivanovs. Good guys capable of shady deals. Various medical personnel on either side of the war, in Los Angeles. The late Gerald Kingman and Gavin Russo, both killed with swords.  Ryuki's a suspect, but so are a number of other people.  Guys into magic tend to also be into swords, though they're usually not functional ones.

This was a bad time for portentous dreams, he thought.  Like he had time.  After spending basically the whole night up with the Dylans, Ryuki hopped on a two hour flight back to the bay, planning a nap to get him through work that day.  The nap had to be interrupted by a dream, and possibly someone else's to boot.  Bother. In the dream he wasn't himself--he was a divorced, middle-aged woman.  He didn't know her name or much about her but that was the nature of dreams.  Sometimes you were a different age or race or even species, though it was rare of him to switch genders.  She-himself had an ex-husband who had reappeared in her life and intended to mooch off her a bit, living in her home and claiming to go to work every day when she had strong suspicions he was doing no such thing.  So far not too far a stretch from Ryuki's own expectations:  moochers kind of came with privilege.  In this dream the ex had spread a rumor that her brother had gone violently mad, probably a a ruse to isolate an older brother from protecting his younger sister as a brother does, and perhaps to make friends uncomfortable approaching any serious subject with her.  He saw right through it.  This curiously short fellow led her and some friends, for some reason, down a steep set of stairs into a subway station.  Five floors down, he didn't know why five, but when they got there the place was awe-inspiring.  The walls were coal black so you could not really see the depth of them, and in front of them were edifices made of limestone or marble or ice, a blindingly white substance without shine.  The effect suggested blacklight without actually bearing that purple hue, and it was awesome.  The dreamer's short ex stopped and gaped, along with her and the friends with them.  Then she/Ryuki snapped out of awe and came to a lucid thought--if the ex had taken this subway to work every day, he would cease to be awestruck by its beauty.  He was awestruck, however, and revealed to be a liar, a fraud, a moocher. He woke as the plane landed, before sending the dream-guy away.  Annoyed and wondering whether he'd truly jumped in to someone else's dream, he picked up a bottle of water and energy drink to get him through the day.  Morning workout was light and the shower chilly, and he'd get through it alright. He got into the office on time, no clear signs of the night he'd had.  "You have another 4:30 appointment," Nicole told him, indicating the type of appointment by failing to say more. "IHS?"  Ryuki used the cover name he'd started for angelic business back at his graduation party. "He appears to be.  'Harry Stone', said he was a judge but didn't correct me when I called him 'Your Honor' at the office.  Either he's really fond of the title or he's not a justice." "And just a name?" "That's all he'd give me." "And he has an appointment?  Nicole, you're slipping."  It was a tease but one with truth in it. "He dropped a name or two." "That's better.  I'll have to give you more on what to expect from these people." And with that he went through his ordinary day, wondering who or what precisely 'Harry Stone' was.  He called Gerhard's old number again, despite knowing that the angel who was Gerhard now went by another role, and got the answer he expected, which was none at all. Harry Stone, he thought, I know that name from somewhere.  He asked the magic box aka his internet browser and it made sense:  the name was a character from "Night Court", a show he used to watch staying up late babysitting his siblings. Seraph? he wondered.  Or just an angel with a shallow role? --------------------------------------a little later---------------------- A few appointments later he came up with a plan.  Excusing himself when a client cancelled, Ryuki acted on the advice from the dream.  The liar is revealed when he is awestruck by something he should have seen everyday, he thought.  So what beautiful thing does a human being see every day that an angel would find entrancing? It was a harder question than it first appeared, since he himself would take those things for granted.  He hoofed it to the local pet shop and looked around.  No cats or dogs, not at the office.  Something visual...  He stopped to look at the golden snails but found himself enchanted by their dreamy dancelike motion, and decided they were too pretty for his purposes (and that sleep deprivation was bad for him).  Near them, however, was a rack of betta fish.  Not as low maintenance as the snail would be, sure, but still not a terrible burden between him and his brother.  He moved four similar-looking fish together and chose one of two that he really couldn't tell apart, a common enough looking fellow for a fish. He got it back to his office and plunked it down on his desk in its classy but plain little bowl.  He shifted it over to one side so his guest's gaze would not naturally fall on it, and then teased the little creature into puffing up.  Satisfied that he had an ordinary fish to lure a very special bird with, he napped in his chair until Nicole informed him that his next appointment was on the way.  He plodded through it, a patient client who trusted him well enough to forgive a lapse.  Afterwards he called Nicole again. "Hey."  He was tired, but he was also feeling puckish.  "Can you tell 'Harry Stone' to postpone, say until Friday?  See if you can get any more information out of him." "I'll try, boss." "And if the front desk can spare you a sec, I'd like to brief you on what to expect.  Confidentially." "Of course."  Nicole was a professional who believed, like most people who knew him, that Ryuki suffered from persistent but largely harmless delusions.  This belief was barely touched by the existence of "IHS" (in hoc signus, if her research was correct) but as always it was a premise on which he and thus she would base action, with little regard for objective reality except to warn his father when the rabbit hole got too deep.  She took notes on titles and quirks as if IHS were just another company and not the company of angels he told her truthfully that they were.  He knew she was humoring him but saw no reason to lie.  Best she hear the truth and not believe it than hear a plausible lie that contained a dangerous omission of fact. Exhausted by his own life, Ryuki went home early that day.

I'm slightly inebriated and otherwise not all there, but aware enough to know that the Angelfire page is low on capacity.  So these are notes on the characters who come to mind:

Ruby
independent Lilim, formerly of Lust
theme song:  Poe: Angry Johnny
While L.A. is in fact a renegade town since 2000, this lady told herself that power equalled freedom and collected as much of it as she could.  Her own vessel looks a bit like the late Brittany Murphy, but in dangerous situations she'll call in a favor and use someone else's, preferably someone prettier or slinkier's
While she has an extensive web of geasa-based power (and some mere alliances, a couple arguable friendships and a couple arguable slaves), she still has to be mindful of Hell itself. 
song:  Nancy Sinatra:  These Boots Are Made for Walking
Because Ruby can't take on a demon prince herself.  Fortunately the rest of the folks in L.A. hate the Game as much as she does, and Gamesters are generally sent home the hard way.  Ajeosshi was more powerful than most, but otherwise the only thing unusual about his fate was that angels were involved.
Ryuki is a business competitor and she treats him as such, as long as you consider geasing someone into a very compromising position to be mere business--as she does.  She may have the Enslavement Song--she's certainly convinced him that she has. 

Ajeosshi
(the name is from Ajeossi, which is a Korean word meaning uncle or protector, possibly Big Brother)
Like most Gamesters he was ambitious, and like most he got smashed to roadkill when he tried to 'enforce' in L.A.  When he insinuated that he had a powerful backer, was he bluffing?
Although he was defeated, his vessel-death and Trauma were actually self-inflicted.  By hiding the Humanity (Song?) he prompted the angels to overdose him.  The Game takes traitors poorly, and giving the angels a chance to question him...tsk tsk.

He had a Soldier of Hell with him, a long-serving young fellow.  He was also able to hijack at least some of Ruby's minions, though by Song or force or fear...well, certainly could have been all three.

Am I doing the right thing?  he thought, but it wasn't really a question.  Of course I'm doing the right thing.  Who else is going to be there, on such short notice?  Marty, maybe, but he's probably working tonight.  Pylus, their angel from Dreams?  Maybe, but how could he possibly understand what they were going through?  Even with centuries of experience you can't know what it is to be a parent with a sick kid, can't know--well, maybe can't know--what it is to have a brother who might not make it back.  Maybe they did get the latter, it's true.  But there was so much he understood that someone outside their Dirty Dozenish could not, and he had to be there, for Karen if no one else.  He had to be an equal, not a boss, but an experienced equal who knew what to tell a doctor and how to deal with being a Cassandra. 

When he knocked on the Dylan family door he knew at that moment that he'd done the right thing.  They were all awake and crushed him in a hug the minute he walked in the door.  I'm doing the right thing, he thought, the only question is Can I convince the angel of that?  And he didn't know Pylus, and Pylus didn't know him, and that was going to be an uphill battle made more difficult by his own lack of Superior.

That was only partly by accident.  He was sincere about Judgement, liked the simplicity and authority of that archangel, liked that it represented the polar opposite of what Corat's stood for while still standing on the same side.  Part of that was hedging his bets--if things did go sideways among angels he wanted to be in between as a peacemaker, not on one side killing and dying.  Much of that was his inherent curiosity--he'd pick up bits from both opposites and have to puzzle them together, and puzzles always thrilled him.  But she said no, and he wasn't going to disgrace either of them by an appeal.  He would have to find another.

Marty and Kevin, both wise men and close friends, nudged him towards Michael.  He held a terrific amount of informal authority by way of history, as opposed to Laurence's formal authority.  He'd grok the rebelliousness, the headstrong tendency to do things one's own way, to occasionally buck orders.  And he loved to fight--despite getting older and more responsible and despite facial surgery, Ryuki still loved the barfight.  As long as the other guy understood it for the bonding and recreation that it was, and most guys did, it was purely a good time, and Michael's angels would definitely approve.  It looked like the perfect match, except...

The War, the angel wars, was in Ryuki's mind exactly what was wrong with the whole situation.  It drove them to compromises, to sacrifice people and fellow angels for mere objectives, to fight and make noise.  And had there been no war maybe, just maybe Eli would not have hidden, and his family wouild not carry its mixed blessing, he might have grown up with both parents together, might not have had to learn to lie so much so young.  War was his one big beef, and he'd have a hard time looking Michael in eye (well, discounting that whole head explodey feeling) and not telling him that his Word was inherently wrong...even if you included ordinary human wars, which were a whole other category.

He sat down at the table, accepted their tea, and talked with the Dylans about what was going on.

See, Julia is a hungry ghost and Corat has a tiny little jar of blood. He got it from Ryuki, who's not volunteering where he got it. But it works and she dives after it before giving up the name of her lover. Bah. Sunae's sword wants a piece of her so badly it's begging.

And Ruby's on a motorcycle leading a grip of cars through suburbia to take down the foolish angel who robbed...curious how she knows there's something of worth there. Or maybe it's just bugging her that there's an angel or four on her turf. That wormhole that Dignity and Nisroc are Singing, that should alert the whole neighborhood? Nope—Ash can muffle Disturbance. The demons have no idea who they're facing or how many. Or how well-dressed. Sunae's options are a formal cheongsam or whatever clothes she can scrounge. Yves looked up from the book he had in hand at the new petitioner in his library. While he didn't have true precognition, not under most circumstances anyway, he could sniff and surmise and decide that this guest could touch the profound truths of the Symphony. He gave the newcomer his full attention, discarding the Distracted Old Man as well as he could. “Come in, come in.”...

 

...When the conversation turned deeper he shifted forms to that of a matronly black woman. He was quoting The Matrix, hoping his guest would catch the reference. Not the haughty old Architect but the comforting and wise and slightly mad Oracle. “There's this book,” she said, poking through some more ordinary archives for just the volume. “Chanced on it really. A nice explanation of evolution.” She waved away her guest's concern. “It is quite relevant to the subject at hand. Be patient.” She flipped the cover open to the title page, The Evolution of Consciousness. “Not the most recent book on the topic, but one with a premise that illustrates your question perfectly. Imagine the human mind...”

 

Another objection waved away. Yves was going to take her time with this explanation; cutting to the chase would give grave injustice to a topic so very serious. “Imagine the human organism as a ship, a great ocean liner with a crew of hundreds. You have that picture? Except instead of trained and resourceful crew you have a collection of simple creatures. One knows how to keep the boiler running but is pointless for navigation. Another can read the waves but has no concept of stars. Et cetera et cetera, hundreds of these specialized simpletons. Together, for different reasons, they manage to sail this ship. After all there have been billions of ships, and simple odds say that some of them will survive.”

 

The guest nodded, fussed a little, urged Yves to continue if there was more to say.

 

“Now, in all of those simple-creature crewmen, you have one whose job it is to watch the clock. It can think back, hmmm, a couple hours ago the weather was fine, and now it's choppy. So says the weather creature. It can think forward: now we have enough fuel, but soon we will be low again, so says the fuel creature. For all this fine thinking our clock-watcher fancies himself bright. He puts the clock by the wheel and tells the wheelman (who ignores him half the time) where to steer, and imagines himself the captain, imagines himself a self, the mind of the ship. He's wrong of course; the ship has no mind, it is only wood and metal and a hundred very lucky simple creatures. And this, Mr. Ornstein tells us, is the human mind. He's not far off.”

 

The guest nodded sagely. It was an odd way of looking at things, but one worth turning over a bit.

 

“And that captain is me.” Yves watched with amused satisfaction the look on her guest's face, the look she never grew tired of. It was the look of a mind being blown apart by a radical new idea then reforming around that idea, shattered momentarily and then whole as though whole were an inevitable state. “And the ship is the Host, and we were all one Godhead once. And then we—at the time I—chose to shatter myself, to break the Mind into its component parts.” The guest was horrified; Yves was saying in essence that God was mad and had committed suicide. “Why? I don't recall exactly. There was something to be learned. Perhaps there was something to be tested: would we reassemble? Can we? Can we ever be One again? I don't know, but I believe. That's what we have, isn't it? Faith. Faith that our simple natures need each other, demon and angel alike.

 

“Yes, demons were part of the plan—I figured that out after a time. Why else leave Heaven but to move among humanity, to protect them? And incidentally to see what Whole looks like. Oh sure, whole but wildly imperfect. It could take another billion years of evolution for them to be perfected if it ever happens at all, but then it could take another billion years for us to be whole again, though were are in totality perfect.

 

“A race, a contest? No. We should learn from each other, ideally to reach the whole-perfect together. But that part I don't know the plan, if there even is a plan, if there's anything more than simple faith...”

 

Yves grew tired of the woman's vessel and slipped back into the Distracted Old Man. It reflected him better anyway right now; all this profound talk of the Great Work upset him and pushed his simple creature's mind to its limits. He let the book fall and sought some lighter reading, disappearing into the stacks among the Existentialists.

Well, that went better than I expected.  Ryuki sat down on his bed to gather his thoughts, and to sober up enough to contact his uncle Shiro.  Shiro and he had often been drinking buddies, so being a little tipsy and smelling of bar might get his attention, let him enjoy the nostalgia.  Being dead had to suck, and Ryuki would provide any little comfort he could.  Instead of washing, as was the usual prerequisite for talking to kami, he went to the shrine garden as he was, stopping in the kitchen for a bowl of rice to offer.  Miyako gave him token resistance, it was her kitchen and how dare a man defile it.

Ryuki gave the proper greetings to the spirits that had been his family members, clapping and bowing in the correct sequence and leaving a few pennies in the box.  He then walked off the path and over the gravel to his uncle's marker, careful not to cross the paths of the guide statues.  He knelt at the shrine and left the bowl of rice there, chatting briefly and intimately with Shiro as he had done often in both life and death.  A tiny cold spot drifted through his space, settling momentarily on the briefcase at the shrine's base, the one that Shiro had on him the night he died.  As a sign it was ambiguous, but Ryuki had faith.  As much as he tested and teased, in this he had faith.

Possessed?!?  "It's not possible!" he said, all wounded pride, and he meant it.  It shouldn't be possible--plenty had tried and failed.  The only time any demon had gotten in was when he'd invited it, as part of an exorcism.

"Create a trap inside your soul," the bishop had said in Russian.  "Create a box and entice it inside, out of the poor victim it already has.  It knows it's a trap so you'll have to be very persuasive.  Once it's in you close the  box and crush it, suffocate the demon with your faith and your will.  Faith in God is best, but since we are discussing how a layman might do it..."  He let the thought hang, and Pavel checked that Ryuki was understanding the language.  He was.  "But be mindful;  even inside its box that demon can get in your mind, learn everything you know, seeking something it can use to bully or persuade you to let it out.  Let only those you trust assist you, as the demon will shame you in every way it knows how.  It will find your deepest secret, and reveal it, to try to preserve itself."

Ryuki remembered those words in particular as the woman tackled him to the ground.  It would find his secret child, it would reveal her to those who might use her, and shame him for being an unwed father.  It would try to wrest that secret out of him--it must fail or die.

He released control of his body to the demon, putting up only enough fight to keep the demon distracted.  It did what it could, but his trust in his friends new and old was well-placed.  A few minor bruises, a bump on the head, a bad charley horse tomorrow if he didn't stretch it out, nothing he wouldn't have gotten from a night of overindulgence.  Instead he steeled his mind and soul against the intruder, aware that he'd built no trap this time.

The ruse fooled it for just a minute, long enough to draw others near.  I'm sorry Marty, he thought, but if it jumps to you at least then I can attack it from the outside.   It gave his body one great twist and then dove into his mind.  Up until then it could read his surface thoughts, know his moves a second before he could make them.  "...in your possession" was the closest he'd gotten to working around this internal censor.  Now it dug deep like a badger, worming a steel tentacle through the labyrinth of his mind.  He fought for his soul, for his reason for living, but he knew he couldn't sustain the fight.  It would win, it would know. 

"Poor tired fellow," it spoke inside his head.  "This fight is futile for both of us you know?"  Vetis knew he couldn't take the sorcerer by pure power, that he had to wheedle and seduce.  Which was easy, when his mind was laid bare.  "I'll stop fighting, you stop fighting.  I'll give you back total control, body and mind.  I'll stop digging."

Ryuki wanted to believe it.  He knew better, knew this foul flea for what it was, but it was a beautiful lie to a desperate man.  He stopped the fight for just a second, testing to see if it would press the attack.  It did not.

"I'll stop, I'll give you back, you just have to promise to leave me be.  Don't fight me and I won't fight you.  This place is crawling with angels who will kill me just for being.  You are my salvation.  I will remember your favor, and repay it someday.  You won't regret this."

"Promise me on your name."  It was the one guarantee he could get under the circumstances, summon the lousy flea later if it lied.

"My name is Vetis, servitor of Nybbas.  I promise to give you back control of body and mind."

Ryuki hesistated.  There was always a catch.  Would the freedom give him the ability to renew the fight later?

"Yes of course.  But today...you won't even know I'm here."

Which was the catch.
